title: 2 Corinthians Chapter 7 Quiz - Multi-Level
description: An enhanced quiz on 2 Corinthians chapter 7 with Easy, Medium, Hard, and Theological levels. Each level has 15 carefully crafted questions. Choose your difficulty and dive in!

easy.title: 2 Corinthians Chapter 7 Quiz - Easy Level
easy.description: Perfect for beginners! Test your basic knowledge of 2 Corinthians Chapter 7.

questions.question: According to 2 Corinthians 7:1, what should we cleanse ourselves from?
options: All filthiness of the flesh and spirit
questions.correctAnswer: All filthiness of the flesh and spirit
questions.explanation: 2 Corinthians 7:1 instructs us to cleanse ourselves from all filthiness of the flesh and spirit, perfecting holiness in the fear of God.

questions.question: In 2 Corinthians 7:2, what does Paul say they have not done?
options: Wronged, corrupted, or defrauded any man
questions.correctAnswer: Wronged, corrupted, or defrauded any man
questions.explanation: Paul states in 2 Corinthians 7:2 that they have wronged no man, corrupted no man, and defrauded no man.

questions.question: What does Paul say about the Corinthians in 2 Corinthians 7:3?
options: They are in his heart to die and live with them
questions.correctAnswer: They are in his heart to die and live with them
questions.explanation: In 2 Corinthians 7:3, Paul expresses that the Corinthians are in his heart to die and live with them, showing his deep affection.

questions.question: According to 2 Corinthians 7:4, how does Paul describe his feelings toward the Corinthians?
options: Filled with comfort and exceeding joyful
questions.correctAnswer: Filled with comfort and exceeding joyful
questions.explanation: Paul says in 2 Corinthians 7:4 that he is filled with comfort and exceedingly joyful in all their tribulation, showing his boldness and glorying in them.

questions.question: Where were Paul and his companions when their flesh had no rest, according to 2 Corinthians 7:5?
questions.correctAnswer: Macedonia
questions.explanation: 2 Corinthians 7:5 states that when they came into Macedonia, their flesh had no rest and they were troubled on every side.

questions.question: Who comforted Paul and his companions in 2 Corinthians 7:6?
options: God by the coming of Titus
questions.correctAnswer: God by the coming of Titus
questions.explanation: In 2 Corinthians 7:6, Paul explains that God comforted them by the coming of Titus.

questions.question: What did Titus report that caused Paul to rejoice, according to 2 Corinthians 7:7?
options: The earnest desire, mourning, and fervent mind of the Corinthians
The financial support from the Corinthians
questions.correctAnswer: The earnest desire, mourning, and fervent mind of the Corinthians
questions.explanation: 2 Corinthians 7:7 says Titus reported the earnest desire, mourning, and fervent mind of the Corinthians, which made Paul rejoice.

questions.question: True or False: According to 2 Corinthians 7:8, Paul repents for making the Corinthians sorry with a letter.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: 2 Corinthians 7:8 states that Paul does not repent for making them sorry with a letter, though he did repent that it made them sorry for a season.

questions.question: According to 2 Corinthians 7:10, what does godly sorrow work?
questions.correctAnswer: Repentance to salvation
questions.explanation: 2 Corinthians 7:10 explains that godly sorrow works repentance unto salvation, unlike the sorrow of the world which works death.

questions.question: What is NOT mentioned as a result of the Corinthians' godly sorrow in 2 Corinthians 7:11?
options: Carefulness, clearing of selves, indignation, fear, vehement desire, zeal, revenge
questions.correctAnswer: Joy, peace, patience, kindness
questions.explanation: 2 Corinthians 7:11 lists carefulness, clearing of selves, indignation, fear, vehement desire, zeal, and revenge as results of godly sorrow, but not joy, peace, patience, or kindness.

questions.question: In 2 Corinthians 7:12, why did Paul write to the Corinthians?
options: To show their care for them in the sight of God
To punish the one who did wrong
To shame the one who suffered wrong
questions.correctAnswer: To show their care for them in the sight of God
questions.explanation: Paul explains in 2 Corinthians 7:12 that he wrote not for the wrongdoer or the wronged, but that their care for the Corinthians in God's sight might appear.

questions.question: True or False: 2 Corinthians 7:14 says Paul is ashamed of boasting about the Corinthians to Titus.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: 2 Corinthians 7:14 states Paul is not ashamed of boasting about the Corinthians to Titus because his boasting was true.

questions.question: Complete the verse from 2 Corinthians 7:16: 'I rejoice therefore that I have ______ in you in all things.'
questions.correctAnswer: confidence
questions.explanation: 2 Corinthians 7:16 says Paul rejoices that he has confidence in the Corinthians in all things.

questions.question: How did the Corinthians receive Titus, according to 2 Corinthians 7:15?
questions.correctAnswer: With fear and trembling
questions.explanation: 2 Corinthians 7:15 says Titus remembers the Corinthians' obedience and how they received him with fear and trembling.

questions.question: True or False: 2 Corinthians 7:9 teaches that sorrow after a godly manner brings damage by Paul and his companions.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: 2 Corinthians 7:9 says godly sorrow leads to repentance so that they might receive damage by Paul and his companions in nothing, meaning no damage was caused.

medium.title: 2 Corinthians Chapter 7 Quiz - Medium Level
medium.description: Ready for more? Apply biblical truths from 2 Corinthians Chapter 7 to real-life situations.

questions.question: How does 2 Corinthians 7:1 teach us about spiritual discipline and holiness in daily life?
options: By cleansing ourselves from all filthiness of flesh and spirit, perfecting holiness in the fear of God
By avoiding all social gatherings and worldly pleasures
By only focusing on external religious rituals
By neglecting the spirit and focusing on the flesh
questions.correctAnswer: By cleansing ourselves from all filthiness of flesh and spirit, perfecting holiness in the fear of God
questions.explanation: 2 Corinthians 7:1 calls believers to cleanse themselves from all impurity, both of flesh and spirit, and to perfect holiness in the fear of God. This highlights the importance of personal spiritual discipline and reverence for God in living a holy life. This teaching is supported by verses 7:1, 7:10, and 7:11 which emphasize godly sorrow and repentance leading to holiness.

questions.question: A believer feels troubled by inner fears and external conflicts. What encouragement from 2 Corinthians 7 could you share?
options: God comforts those who are cast down, as He comforted Paul through Titus' arrival
They should isolate themselves until troubles pass
Physical rest is the only solution for troubles
Avoid facing fears by ignoring them
questions.correctAnswer: God comforts those who are cast down, as He comforted Paul through Titus' arrival
questions.explanation: In 2 Corinthians 7:5-6, Paul shares that despite being deeply troubled both externally and internally, God provided comfort through the arrival of Titus, showing that divine comfort comes even in hardship. This encourages believers to trust God's comfort during trials.

questions.question: According to 2 Corinthians 7:9-10, what kind of sorrow leads to positive spiritual change?
options: Godly sorrow that leads to repentance and salvation
Sorrow that causes despair and hopelessness
Worldly sorrow that leads to death
Sorrow that is ignored and suppressed
questions.correctAnswer: Godly sorrow that leads to repentance and salvation
questions.explanation: Verses 7:9-10 contrast godly sorrow, which produces repentance leading to salvation, with worldly sorrow, which leads to death. This teaches believers that godly sorrow is a necessary part of spiritual growth and transformation.

questions.question: What does 2 Corinthians 7:2 reveal about integrity in relationships within the Christian community?
options: Paul asserts they have wronged no one, corrupted no one, and defrauded no one
Paul admits to wronging some to teach a lesson
Paul encourages taking advantage of others for ministry success
Paul suggests ignoring wrongs to maintain peace
questions.correctAnswer: Paul asserts they have wronged no one, corrupted no one, and defrauded no one
questions.explanation: In verse 7:2, Paul emphasizes the importance of integrity, stating that he and his companions have not wronged, corrupted, or defrauded anyone. This teaches believers to maintain honesty and fairness in all relationships.

questions.question: How does 2 Corinthians 7:4 encourage believers in times of tribulation?
options: Paul expresses boldness and joy even amid tribulation, finding comfort in God
Paul advises fleeing troubles to avoid discomfort
Paul suggests ignoring difficulties to pretend all is well
Paul warns against expressing joy during hardships
questions.correctAnswer: Paul expresses boldness and joy even amid tribulation, finding comfort in God
questions.explanation: Verse 7:4 shows Paul’s boldness and joy despite tribulations, highlighting that comfort and joy come through faith, encouraging believers to maintain a joyful spirit in trials.

questions.question: True or False: According to 2 Corinthians 7:16, Paul has complete confidence in the Corinthians in all things.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: 2 Corinthians 7:16 explicitly states Paul’s confidence in the Corinthians, reflecting trust in their obedience and faithfulness.

questions.question: What practical lesson about repentance can be learned from Paul's purpose in writing, according to 2 Corinthians 7:8 and 7:12?
options: Paul wrote to encourage godly sorrow and repentance, not to condemn or punish
Paul wrote to shame the Corinthians publicly
Paul wrote to assert his authority harshly
Paul wrote only to correct one individual without concern for the whole church
questions.correctAnswer: Paul wrote to encourage godly sorrow and repentance, not to condemn or punish
questions.explanation: Verses 7:8 and 7:12 clarify that Paul’s letter was intended to bring godly sorrow leading to repentance and to show care for the believers before God, not to condemn or shame.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: According to 2 Corinthians 7:11, godly sorrow produces __________, clearing of selves, indignation, fear, vehement desire, zeal, and revenge.
questions.correctAnswer: carefulness
questions.explanation: Verse 7:11 lists carefulness as one of the fruits of godly sorrow, showing how repentance leads to earnest reflection and right action.

questions.question: How does the arrival of Titus, as described in 2 Corinthians 7:6-7, model the importance of fellowship and encouragement in the church?
options: Titus’ visit brought comfort and encouragement through sharing the Corinthians’ earnest desire and mourning
Titus criticized the church harshly and caused division
Titus ignored the Corinthians’ feelings and focused on Paul only
Titus discouraged the believers from repentance
questions.correctAnswer: Titus’ visit brought comfort and encouragement through sharing the Corinthians’ earnest desire and mourning
questions.explanation: Verses 7:6-7 show that God used Titus’ arrival to comfort Paul by reporting the Corinthians’ repentance and earnestness, demonstrating the role of mutual encouragement in church life.

questions.question: True or False: According to 2 Corinthians 7:15, Titus' affection toward the Corinthians increased because of their obedience and respectful reception.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Verse 7:15 states that Titus’ inward affection grew as he remembered how the Corinthians received him with fear and trembling, highlighting the value of obedience and reverence.

questions.question: According to 2 Corinthians 7:3, what is Paul’s attitude toward the Corinthians despite any previous correction?
options: They are in Paul’s heart to die and live with them, showing deep love and commitment
Paul has given up on them
Paul distances himself from them permanently
questions.correctAnswer: They are in Paul’s heart to die and live with them, showing deep love and commitment
questions.explanation: Verse 7:3 reveals Paul’s tender love and commitment, expressing that the Corinthians are deeply in his heart despite correction.

questions.question: Based on 2 Corinthians 7:14, how important is honesty and truthfulness in ministry relationships?
options: Very important, as Paul’s boasting before Titus was founded on truth
Not important, as exaggeration is acceptable
questions.correctAnswer: Very important, as Paul’s boasting before Titus was founded on truth
questions.explanation: Verse 7:14 emphasizes that Paul spoke truthfully in all things, showing that honesty is essential in ministry and relationships.

questions.question: What does 2 Corinthians 7:16 teach about Paul’s confidence in the spiritual growth of believers?
options: Paul has full confidence in the Corinthians in all things
Paul doubts the Corinthians’ ability to grow
Paul is indifferent about their spiritual state
questions.correctAnswer: Paul has full confidence in the Corinthians in all things
questions.explanation: Verse 7:16 clearly states Paul’s confidence, reflecting encouragement for believers to grow and persevere in faith.

questions.question: How does 2 Corinthians 7:13 illustrate the joy found in mutual encouragement within the body of Christ?
options: Paul and his companions were comforted and rejoiced greatly because Titus’ spirit was refreshed by the Corinthians
Paul felt isolated and discouraged by the Corinthians
questions.correctAnswer: Paul and his companions were comforted and rejoiced greatly because Titus’ spirit was refreshed by the Corinthians
questions.explanation: Verse 7:13 shows how encouragement within the church brings mutual comfort and joy, important for sustaining believers.

questions.question: According to 2 Corinthians 7:11, what are some of the outcomes of godly sorrow that believers should pursue?
options: Carefulness, clearing of selves, indignation, fear, vehement desire, zeal, and revenge
questions.correctAnswer: Carefulness, clearing of selves, indignation, fear, vehement desire, zeal, and revenge
questions.explanation: Verse 7:11 lists these outcomes as fruits of godly sorrow, showing the transformative power of true repentance.

hard.title: 2 Corinthians Chapter 7 Quiz - Hard Level
hard.description: Challenge yourself with deep analysis and cross-biblical connections from 2 Corinthians Chapter 7.

questions.question: In 2 Corinthians 7:1, Paul urges believers to cleanse themselves from all filthiness of the flesh and spirit. This call to holiness parallels which Old Testament concept emphasizing purity before God?
questions.correctAnswer: The holiness code in Leviticus 19
questions.explanation: 2 Corinthians 7:1 calls for perfecting holiness, echoing the holiness code in Leviticus 19 which emphasizes moral and ritual purity before God.

questions.question: Paul speaks of being 'filled with comfort' and 'exceeding joyful in all our tribulation' in 2 Corinthians 7:4. This attitude aligns closely with which New Testament teaching about suffering?
options: James 1:2-4's call to consider trials as joy for perseverance
questions.correctAnswer: James 1:2-4's call to consider trials as joy for perseverance
questions.explanation: Paul’s joy in tribulation (2 Corinthians 7:4) resonates with James 1:2-4, which encourages believers to find joy in trials as they produce perseverance.

questions.question: In 2 Corinthians 7:5, Paul describes his experience in Macedonia as having 'no rest' due to external fightings and internal fears. This dual struggle exemplifies which ancient Near Eastern trope often found in lament Psalms?
options: The motif of distress from both enemies and inner turmoil
The royal enthronement of the king
The creation chaos followed by order
questions.correctAnswer: The motif of distress from both enemies and inner turmoil
questions.explanation: The description in 2 Corinthians 7:5 matches lament Psalms where the psalmist often faces external enemies and internal fear simultaneously.

questions.question: The comfort Paul received through Titus, as described in 2 Corinthians 7:6-7, illustrates which type of early Christian interpersonal ministry?
options: Encouragement through mutual fellowship and report of repentance
questions.correctAnswer: Encouragement through mutual fellowship and report of repentance
questions.explanation: Titus’s arrival brought comfort by sharing news of the Corinthians’ repentance, exemplifying early Christian fellowship and mutual encouragement (2 Corinthians 7:6-7).

questions.question: Paul refers to having made the Corinthians 'sorry with a letter' in 2 Corinthians 7:8. This is an example of which rhetorical strategy employed by Paul to effect repentance?
questions.correctAnswer: Constructive confrontation
questions.explanation: Paul’s letter provoked godly sorrow (2 Corinthians 7:8), demonstrating constructive confrontation to promote repentance.

questions.question: According to 2 Corinthians 7:9-10, what is the key difference between 'godly sorrow' and 'sorrow of the world'?
options: 'Godly sorrow leads to repentance and salvation; worldly sorrow leads to death.'
'Godly sorrow is temporary; worldly sorrow is eternal.'
'Godly sorrow manifests in outward tears; worldly sorrow is silent.'
'Godly sorrow is public; worldly sorrow is private.'
questions.correctAnswer: 'Godly sorrow leads to repentance and salvation; worldly sorrow leads to death.'
questions.explanation: 2 Corinthians 7:10 clearly differentiates godly sorrow as leading to salvation through repentance, whereas worldly sorrow leads to spiritual death.

questions.question: The detailed list of responses to godly sorrow in 2 Corinthians 7:11 (carefulness, clearing, indignation, fear, desire, zeal, revenge) is an example of which literary device?
questions.correctAnswer: Polysyndeton
questions.explanation: The use of multiple conjunctions in 2 Corinthians 7:11 to link many emotions and actions is polysyndeton, emphasizing the intensity of godly sorrow.

questions.question: In 2 Corinthians 7:12, Paul explains his letter was written to show their care in the sight of God. This reflects which theological concept regarding Christian accountability?
questions.correctAnswer: Divine oversight of church discipline
questions.explanation: Paul’s concern in 2 Corinthians 7:12 highlights that church discipline and care are accountable before God, affirming divine oversight.

questions.question: The joy Paul and his companions experience due to Titus’s refreshed spirit in 2 Corinthians 7:13 is an example of what type of communal dynamic in early Christian missions?
questions.correctAnswer: Mutual encouragement and spiritual refreshing
questions.explanation: 2 Corinthians 7:13 depicts how mutual encouragement among believers, like Titus’s refreshed spirit, was vital in early Christian mission dynamics.

questions.question: Paul’s confidence in the Corinthians expressed in 2 Corinthians 7:16 reflects which recurring Pauline theme about the relationship between apostle and church?
questions.correctAnswer: Mutual trust and spiritual partnership
questions.explanation: Paul’s statement in 2 Corinthians 7:16 embodies the theme of mutual trust and partnership in ministry between apostle and believers.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: In 2 Corinthians 7:2, Paul appeals to the Corinthians to 'Receive us; we have wronged no man, we have corrupted no man, we have ______ no man.'
questions.correctAnswer: defrauded
questions.explanation: The verse explicitly states 'we have defrauded no man,' emphasizing Paul’s innocence in dealings with the Corinthians.

questions.question: True or False: In 2 Corinthians 7:15, Paul notes that Titus’s inward affection toward the Corinthians decreased despite their obedience.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: 2 Corinthians 7:15 states Titus's inward affection is more abundant toward the Corinthians because of their obedience, not less.

questions.question: Paul’s boasting before Titus about the Corinthians in 2 Corinthians 7:14 is an example of what rhetorical function in his epistles?
options: Validation of the church’s repentance and progress
questions.correctAnswer: Validation of the church’s repentance and progress
questions.explanation: Paul’s boasting in 2 Corinthians 7:14 serves to affirm the genuine repentance and faithfulness of the Corinthians.

questions.question: How does the theme of repentance in 2 Corinthians 7 compare to the call to repentance in the prophetic books of the Old Testament?
options: Both emphasize godly sorrow leading to restoration with God
Paul’s call is legalistic, while prophets focus on mercy
Old Testament repentance is purely ritual, Paul’s is ethical
questions.correctAnswer: Both emphasize godly sorrow leading to restoration with God
questions.explanation: 2 Corinthians 7’s focus on godly sorrow leading to repentance aligns with prophetic calls for heartfelt repentance resulting in restoration (e.g., Joel 2).

questions.question: In the context of ancient Greco-Roman letter writing, what is significant about Paul expressing 'great boldness of speech' toward the Corinthians in 2 Corinthians 7:4?
options: It reflects a rhetorical strategy to strengthen communal bonds through frankness
It is a sign of disrespect uncommon in that culture
It imitates the style of Roman governors
questions.correctAnswer: It reflects a rhetorical strategy to strengthen communal bonds through frankness
questions.explanation: Paul’s boldness (2 Corinthians 7:4) fits Greco-Roman rhetorical norms where frank speech was used to build trust and communal integrity.

theological.title: 2 Corinthians Chapter 7 Quiz - Theological Level
theological.description: Deep biblical theology from 2 Corinthians Chapter 7 that unites all believers. Explore foundational truths about God, creation, and humanity.

questions.question: According to 2 Corinthians 7:1, what is the believer exhorted to cleanse themselves from in order to perfect holiness?
options: All filthiness of the flesh and spirit
questions.correctAnswer: All filthiness of the flesh and spirit
questions.explanation: 2 Corinthians 7:1 commands believers to cleanse themselves from all filthiness of the flesh and spirit, perfecting holiness. This echoes Old Testament calls to purity (Leviticus 11:44), New Testament calls to holiness (1 Peter 1:15-16), and the call to mortify the flesh (Romans 8:13).

questions.question: In 2 Corinthians 7:2, Paul appeals to the Corinthians to receive him because he claims they have been wronged in what way?
options: They have been wronged by defrauding and corruption
They have been wronged by persecution
They have been wronged by false teachers
They have been wronged by neglect
questions.correctAnswer: They have been wronged by defrauding and corruption
questions.explanation: Paul asserts in 2 Corinthians 7:2 that he and his companions have wronged no man, have corrupted no man, and have defrauded no man, highlighting their integrity. This theme aligns with biblical principles of justice and honesty (Proverbs 21:3; Acts 24:16).

questions.question: What attitude does Paul express toward the Corinthians in 2 Corinthians 7:3?
options: They are in his heart to die and live with them
He is condemning them for their sins
He doubts their faith and commitment
He is indifferent to their spiritual condition
questions.correctAnswer: They are in his heart to die and live with them
questions.explanation: Paul states in 2 Corinthians 7:3 that he does not speak to condemn, but that the Corinthians are in his heart to die and live with them, showing deep pastoral love consistent with Christ's love for the church (John 15:13; Philippians 1:8).

questions.question: According to 2 Corinthians 7:4, what is Paul's emotional state despite tribulation?
options: Filled with comfort and exceedingly joyful
questions.correctAnswer: Filled with comfort and exceedingly joyful
questions.explanation: Paul expresses in 2 Corinthians 7:4 that he is filled with comfort and exceedingly joyful despite tribulations, reflecting the biblical theme of joy in suffering (James 1:2-3; Romans 5:3-5).

questions.question: What describes the conditions Paul and his companions faced upon arriving in Macedonia according to 2 Corinthians 7:5?
options: Their flesh had no rest; they were troubled on every side
They were welcomed with peace and rest
They experienced miraculous provision and safety
They found great encouragement and support
questions.correctAnswer: Their flesh had no rest; they were troubled on every side
questions.explanation: 2 Corinthians 7:5 describes Paul’s hardships in Macedonia with no rest and troubles on every side, illustrating the reality of apostolic suffering in ministry (2 Timothy 3:12; Acts 20:23-24).

questions.question: Who does Paul say comforted them in their distress, as recorded in 2 Corinthians 7:6?
options: God, through the coming of Titus
questions.correctAnswer: God, through the coming of Titus
questions.explanation: Paul acknowledges in 2 Corinthians 7:6 that God comforts those who are cast down, and He comforted them through Titus’ arrival, highlighting God's providential care (Psalm 34:18; Isaiah 51:12).

questions.question: According to 2 Corinthians 7:7, what did Titus report that caused Paul to rejoice even more?
options: The Corinthians’ earnest desire, mourning, and fervent mind toward Paul
The financial support sent by the Corinthians
The growth of the church in Macedonia
questions.correctAnswer: The Corinthians’ earnest desire, mourning, and fervent mind toward Paul
questions.explanation: Titus reported the Corinthians’ earnest desire, mourning, and fervent mind toward Paul (2 Corinthians 7:7), evidencing their godly sorrow and repentance (Psalm 51:17; Joel 2:12-13).

questions.question: What does Paul say about the letter that made the Corinthians sorry in 2 Corinthians 7:8?
options: Though it made them sorry, he does not regret sending it
The letter was harsh and condemning
questions.correctAnswer: Though it made them sorry, he does not regret sending it
questions.explanation: Paul states in 2 Corinthians 7:8 that although the letter made the Corinthians sorry, he does not repent of sending it, recognizing godly sorrow as necessary for repentance (Psalm 119:71; Ezekiel 3:18).

questions.question: What type of sorrow does Paul say leads to salvation in 2 Corinthians 7:10?
questions.correctAnswer: Godly sorrow
questions.explanation: 2 Corinthians 7:10 distinguishes godly sorrow as leading to repentance and salvation, unlike worldly sorrow which leads to death, reflecting biblical teaching on repentance (Psalm 34:18; Isaiah 57:15; Luke 22:62).

questions.question: Which of the following was NOT mentioned as a result of godly sorrow in 2 Corinthians 7:11?
questions.correctAnswer: Physical pain
questions.explanation: 2 Corinthians 7:11 lists carefulness, clearing of selves, indignation, fear, vehement desire, zeal, and revenge as results of godly sorrow, but does not mention physical pain, highlighting godly sorrow’s spiritual fruits (Joel 2:13; 2 Timothy 2:25).

questions.question: What was Paul’s purpose in writing to the Corinthians concerning the wrongdoer and the wronged, according to 2 Corinthians 7:12?
options: To make their earnest care for them appear in the sight of God
questions.correctAnswer: To make their earnest care for them appear in the sight of God
questions.explanation: In 2 Corinthians 7:12, Paul explains that his letter was written so that their earnest care for the Corinthians would be evident before God, emphasizing pastoral responsibility and divine accountability (1 Thessalonians 2:4; Hebrews 13:17).

questions.question: What was a cause of great joy for Paul and his companions as noted in 2 Corinthians 7:13?
options: The joy of Titus being refreshed by the Corinthians
The financial gifts sent to Macedonia
questions.correctAnswer: The joy of Titus being refreshed by the Corinthians
questions.explanation: Paul states in 2 Corinthians 7:13 that their comfort was multiplied by the joy of Titus, whose spirit was refreshed by the Corinthians, illustrating mutual encouragement in the body of Christ (Acts 20:37-38; Romans 15:32).

questions.question: What does Paul say about his boasting to Titus concerning the Corinthians in 2 Corinthians 7:14?
options: His boasting was found to be true
He was ashamed of his boasting
He did not boast to Titus
questions.correctAnswer: His boasting was found to be true
questions.explanation: Paul affirms in 2 Corinthians 7:14 that what he boasted to Titus about the Corinthians was true, showing integrity and faithfulness in ministry (Philippians 1:18; 1 Corinthians 9:2).

questions.question: How did Titus's inward affection toward the Corinthians grow, according to 2 Corinthians 7:15?
options: By remembering their obedience and respectful reception of him
questions.correctAnswer: By remembering their obedience and respectful reception of him
questions.explanation: 2 Corinthians 7:15 explains that Titus’s affection grew as he remembered the Corinthians’ obedience and how they received him with fear and trembling, highlighting the importance of respectful submission in the church (Hebrews 13:17; 1 Thessalonians 2:7-8).

questions.question: What is Paul's overall confidence in the Corinthians as expressed in 2 Corinthians 7:16?
options: He has confidence in them in all things
He fears they will fall away
He is indifferent to their progress
questions.correctAnswer: He has confidence in them in all things
questions.explanation: Paul expresses in 2 Corinthians 7:16 his confidence in the Corinthians in all things, underscoring trust and hope in their spiritual maturity (Philippians 1:6; 2 Timothy 1:12).
